title: Periyar National Park
short_description: A scenic elephant and tiger reserve centered around a lake in the Cardamom Hills of Kerala.
long_description: Periyar National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary (PNP) is a protected area near Thekkady in the districts of Idukki, Kottayam and Pathanamthitta in Kerala, India. It is notable as an elephant reserve and a tiger reserve. The park is often called the Periyar Wildlife Sanctuary or Thekkady. It is set high in the Cardamom Hills and Pandalam Hills of the south Western Ghats along the border with Tamil Nadu. The sanctuary surrounds the Periyar Lake, a reservoir formed when the Mullaperiyar Dam was constructed in 1895. The park is known for its herds of Asian elephants who come to bathe in the lake.
wildlife_significance: One of the few places where you can see elephants in close quarters by boat. Part of Western Ghats UNESCO site.
guides_and_tips: Boat tickets often sell out fast; book online or queue up early. Leeches are common on treks; wear leech socks.
how_to_reach: By Air: Madurai (140 km) or Kochi (190 km). By Rail: Kottayam (114 km). Well connected by road.
permits_and_fees: Entry fee and boat tickets can be booked online via Periyar Foundation.
conservation_notes: Community-based eco-tourism programs involve local tribes in conservation.
sample_itinerary: Day 1: Arrive Thekkady. Evening cultural show (Kathakali/Kalaripayattu). Day 2: Early morning Boat Safari. Breakfast. Guided Nature Walk. Afternoon Spice Plantation tour. Day 3: Bamboo Rafting (half day). Departure.
safety_tips: Be quiet on the boat to not scare animals. Follow guide instructions on treks.

operating_season.off_season: June to August (Monsoon - heavy rain but park open)
operating_season.season_notes: Open year-round. Monsoons offer lush greenery but leeches are prevalent.
